TEXT: The applicant company is incorporated under NORP law , has its head office in GPE and is currently under liquidation . It is represented before the Court by Mrs PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
In DATE ORG ( NORP Επικουρικής Ασφαλίσεως FAC Εμπορικών DATE hereinafter TEAYEK ) , a public body under the supervision of ORG , leased to the applicant company a hotel in GPE .

On DATE TEAYEK granted the applicant company the right to convert the hotel into a courthouse and sublease it to the ORG for a period of DATE . On DATE the applicant company entered into an agreement with the ORG and TEAYEK for the sublease of the building to the ORG . The rent would be paid by ORG ( GPE Χρηματοδοτήσεως GPE Κτιρίων – hereinafter TAXDIK ) , a public body , and ORG to ORG and the applicant company .

On DATE the sublease came up for re - negotiation . The applicant company requested a PERCENT increase , which ORG accepted . The ORG refused . However , it did not evacuate the LOC , which it continues using until DATE to house ORG of GPE . ORG , considering that the sublease had been terminated , asked the ORG and ORG to pay it the entire rent . ORG TAXDIK , not knowing to whom to pay the part of the rent that used to be collected by the applicant company , started deposing that part with ORG και NORP ) .

On DATE the applicant company sued the ORG and ORG for its part of the rent from DATE to CARDINAL DATE before the single - member first instance civil court of GPE ( first action ) . On DATE the court accepted the applicant company ’s action ( decision no . DATE concerning the first action ) . On DATE the defendants appealed . On DATE TEAYEK intervened in the proceedings in favour of the appellants .

On DATE ORG enacted a law ( no . DATE ) entitled “ social cover of uninsured groups , improvement of the social security and other provisions ” . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of that law provides for the termination of leases of real property owned by social security funds under the supervision of ORG and Security , if the property is used as commercial premises by a person other than the leaseholder . In that case the lease continues between the owner and the subtenant . It was indicated in the explanatory report that the subleases in question were continuously renewed and were “ unfavourable and unprofitable ” to the funds because it was the leaseholder who made capital of the bigger part of the rent . Thus , the purpose of the provision was to “ stop the exploitation of the social security funds and their pensioners ” .
On DATE ORG of GPE rejected both the appeal of the ORG and ORG and the intervention of TEAYEK ( decision no . DATE concerning the first action ) .

TAXDIK and the ORG appealed in cassation . TEAYEK did not . On DATE ORG rejected the appeal . It held that the sublease was tacitly renewed and that the ORG , which continued to use the building , had to pay the applicant company its part of the rent . ORG made no reference to Law no . DATE ( decision no . DATE concerning the first action ) . Subsequently , the applicant company was paid the amounts fixed .

On DATE the applicant company sued the ORG and ORG for its part of the rent from DATE to CARDINAL DATE before the single - member first instance civil court of GPE ( second action ) . The defendants relied on section QUANTITY no . DATE . The applicant company argued that the provision in question violated the constitutional provisions on equality and separation of powers . ORG intervened in the proceedings claiming the rent for itself . On DATE the court allowed ORG ’s intervention and dismissed the action ( decision no . MONEY concerning the second action ) . The applicant company appealed .

On DATE the applicant company sued the ORG and ORG for its part of the rent from DATE to CARDINAL DATE ( third action ) . On DATE the applicant company sued the ORG and ORG for its part of the rent DATE and DATE ( fourth action ) . ORG intervened in both actions claiming the rent for itself .

On DATE ORG upheld the applicant company ’s appeal against the first instance court ’s decision of DATE on the ground that section QUANTITY no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL did not apply to the case under consideration , which did not concern the lease of “ commercial ” LOC ( decision no . DATE concerning the second action ) . The ORG , ORG and TEAYEK appealed in cassation . The applicant company also appealed arguing that the courts should declare section QUANTITY no . DATE unconstitutional because it violated the right to equal treatment , the right to property and the principle of separation of powers .

On DATE the first instance court allowed the applicant company ’s actions of CARDINAL DATE and DATE on the ground that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL did not apply ( decision no . CARDINAL concerning the third action and decision no . DATE concerning the fourth action ) . The ORG , ORG and TEAYEK appealed . The applicant company also appealed asking the court to declare section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of Law no . DATE unconstitutional .

On DATE the applicant company sued the ORG and ORG for its part of the rent from DATE to CARDINAL DATE ( fifth action ) . PERSON intervened . On DATE the first instance court allowed the action on the ground that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL did not apply ( decision no . CARDINAL concerning the fifth action ) . The ORG , ORG and TEAYEK appealed . So did the applicant company relying on the alleged unconstitutionality of the above provision .

On DATE the applicant company sued the ORG and ORG for its part of the rent from DATE and DATE ( sixth action ) and on DATE it sued them for its part of the rent from CARDINAL DATE and DATE ( seventh action ) . ORG intervened .

On DATE the first instance court allowed the action of DATE on the ground that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL did not apply ( decision no . CARDINAL concerning the sixth action ) . The ORG , ORG and TEAYEK appealed . The appeal is still pending .

On DATE ORG dismissed the appeals of the ORG , ORG and TEAYEK against the first instance decisions of CARDINAL DATE , finding section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of Law no . DATE inapplicable ( decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL concerning the third action and decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL concerning the fourth action ) .
On DATE the applicant company sued the ORG and ORG for its part of the rent from DATE to CARDINAL DATE ( eighth action ) . The proceedings are still pending .

On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal of the ORG , ORG and TEAYEK against the first instance decision of CARDINAL DATE ( decision no . MONEY concerning the fifth action ) . The ORG , ORG and ORG did not appeal in cassation .

On DATE the first instance court allowed the action of DATE on the ground that section QUANTITY no . DATE was inapplicable ( decision no . DATE concerning the seventh action ) . The ORG , ORG and TEAYEK appealed . The appeal is still pending .
On DATE the applicant company sued for its part of the rent from CARDINAL DATE to DATE ( ninth action ) . The proceedings are still pending .
On DATE the applicant company sued for its part of the rent from DATE to DATE ( tenth action ) . The proceedings are still pending .
On DATE the applicant company sued for its part of the rent from DATE to DATE ( eleventh action ) . The proceedings are still pending .

On DATE ORG allowed the ORG ’s , ORG and ORG ’s appeal in cassation against ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE considering that , according to section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , TEAYEK was entitled to the whole rent ( decision no . PERSON concerning the second action ) . However , on the same date it dismissed their appeals in cassation against ORG decisions of CARDINAL DATE ; it considered that ORG had correctly decided the third and fourth actions because at the time it was bound by the res judicata effect of its own decision of CARDINAL DATE ( decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL concerning the third action and decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL concerning the fourth action ) . The applicant company notified these decisions to the ORG and TAXDIK on DATE . Under LAW , the time - limit for introducing remedies against these decisions is of DATE . However , according to a special law , the ORG and ORG could challenge these decisions within a time - limit of DATE .

On DATE the ORG and ORG asked ORG to revise its CARDINAL judgments of CARDINAL DATE and then its judgment of DATE . On DATE ORG granted their first request ( which concerned the CARDINAL judgments of CARDINAL DATE ) , found section QUANTITY no . DATE applicable and not unconstitutional and reversed the first instance judgments ( decision no . CARDINAL concerning the third action and decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL concerning the fourth action ) .
On DATE ORG also revised its judgment of DATE ( decision no . CARDINAL concerning the fifth action ) .

The applicant company appealed in cassation against decisions ORG . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and CARDINAL/CARDINAL . It claimed that the applications for revision were lodged out of time . It also invoked a violation of ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Convention and CARDINAL of Protocol No . CARDINAL .

On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal in cassation as being ill - founded . In the first place , the court considered that the applications for revision were lodged within the time - limit of DATE which applies to recourses filed by the ORG . Moreover , it considered that the applicant company had not sufficiently substantiated its complaints under LAW and CARDINAL of Protocol No . CARDINAL ( decision no . CARDINAL concerning the fourth action and decision no . MONEY concerning the fifth action ) . The above decisions were finalised ( καθαρογραφή ) on DATE and filed ( αρχειοθέτηση ) on DATE . ORG does not serve its judgments . The applicant company became aware of them on DATE .
